So I'm not in any way trying to demonize audiobooks by saying that I don't use them. I definitely do. I just think it's important to point out that I really don't enjoy listening to them much because it isn't the same as reading a real book.

Reading a real book really helps me to get invested in the story and characters. And I always find that I 'm more easily able to form a real, deep connection to the characters of what I'm reading if I can see them and visually connect to their words. Usually when I read, my mind is actively visualizing the book's imagery, which I find is something that can't quite be replicated when listening to someone else read it to me. 

I've had some friends tell me that they really enjoy audiobooks in part because they can make up their own interpretation of the story when they aren't seeing it played out the way the author intended on the page. I can understand this viewpoint, but I don't find much value in it. After all, couldn't I just retort that people don't really know it could have been intended any other way? And who's to say that an audiobook reader doesn't force hi

Is Listening to a Book Just as Good as Reading It?

Do you listen to audiobooks? What are the benefits, in your opinion, of listening instead of reading? Are there advantages to reading that cannot be gained by listening? Which method do you prefer? Why?

In my opinion, audiobooks are not a sufficient replacement for real books. I don't listen to audiobooks because I consider myself to be a visual learner, and while I suppose that good audiobook narrators aim to cater to me, it's just not the same for me. I really have to be seeing it in my mind's eye if I'm to get the full effect of a story. If I'm just listening to someone read it, I don't feel one bit of emotion or connection with the characters. And moreover, it's just that much easier for me to "switch off" when listening to someone else read - particularly if what I'm listening to isn't capturing my attention. Oftentimes, when I'm listening to an audiobook, I'll find myself daydreaming about times I'd rather forget, or something bad that happened today, or my looming deadlines... I just can't concentrate fully on what I'm listening to if my mind is wandering.

This isn't to say that audiobooks can't be tremendously useful, and I do use them occasionally. I mean, if I'm driving, I can't even pretend that it isn't ten times safer for me to be listening to someone else read instead of trying to read myself. Is Listening to a Book Just as Good as Reading It?

Do you listen to audiobooks? What are the benefits, in your opinion, of listening instead of reading? Are there advantages to reading that cannot be gained by listening? Which method do you prefer? Why?

---

In my opinion, audiobooks are not a sufficient replacement for real books. I don't listen to audiobooks because I consider myself to be a visual learner, and while I suppose that good audiobook narrators aim to cater to me, it's just not the same for me. I really have to be seeing it in my mind's eye if I'm to get the full effect of a story. If I'm just listening to someone read it, I don't feel one bit of emotion or connection with the characters. And moreover, it's just that much easier for me to "switch off" when listening to someone else read - particularly if what I'm listening to isn't capturing my attention. Oftentimes, when I'm listening to an audiobook, I'll find myself daydreaming about times I'd rather forget, or something bad that happened today, or my looming deadlines... I just can't concentrate fully on what I'm listening to if my mind is wandering.

This isn't to say that audiobooks can't be tremendously useful, and I do use them occasionally. I mean, if I'm driving, I can't even pretend that it isn't ten times safer for me to be listening to someone else read instead of trying to read myself. On my commute to and from school, I often find that listening to John Scalzi narrate his own audiobooks is enjoyable - even though I don't think I get as much out of the audiobooks as I do from reading them my own. Sometimes, listening to the audiobook version of my science textbook is sufficient to recall the information I need for an exam - although I will caveat that it is not sufficient to really understand it. So I'm not in any way trying to demonize audiobooks by saying that I don't use them. I definitely do. I just think it's important to point out that I really don't enjoy listening to them much because it isn't the same as reading a real book.

Reading a real book really helps me to get invested in the story and characters. And I always find that I 'm more easily able to form a real, deep connection to the characters of what I'm reading if I can see them and visually connect to their words. Usually when I read, my mind is actively visualizing the book's imagery, which I find is something that can't quite be replicated when listening to someone else read it to me. 

I've had some friends tell me that they really enjoy audiobooks in part because they can make up their own interpretation of the story when they aren't seeing it played out the way the author intended on the page. I can understand this viewpoint, but I don't find much value in it. After all, couldn't I just retort that people don't really know it could have been intended any other way? And who's to say that an audiobook vocali doesn't force his or her

Oftentimes, when I'm listening to an audiobook, I'll find myself daydreaming about times I'd rather forget, or something bad that happened today, or my looming deadlines... I just can't concentrate fully on what I'm listening to if my mind is wandering.

This isn't to say that audiobooks can't be tremendously useful, and I do use them occasionally. I mean, if I'm driving, I can't even pretend that it isn't ten times safer for me to be listening to someone else read instead of trying to read myself. On my commute to and from school, I often find that listening to John Scalzi narrate his own audiobooks is enjoyable - even though I don't think I get as much out of the audiobooks as I do from reading them my own. Sometimes, listening to the audiobook version of my science textbook is sufficient to recall the information I need for an exam - although I will caveat that it is not sufficient to really understand it. So I'm not in any way trying to demonize audiobooks by saying that I don't use them. I definitely do. I just think it's important to point out that I really don't enjoy listening to them much because it isn't the same as reading a real book.

Reading a real book really helps me to get invested in the story and characters. And I always find that I 'm more easily able to form a real, deep connection to the characters of what I'm reading if I can see them and visually connect to their words. Usually when I read, my mind is actively visualizing the book's imagery, which I find is something that can't quite be replicated when listening to someone else read it to me. 

I've had some friends tell me that they really enjoy audiobooks in part because they can make up their own interpretation of the story when they aren't seeing it played out the way the author intended on the page. I can understand this viewpoint, but I don't find much value in it. After all, couldn't I just retort that people don't really know it could have been intended any other way? And who's to say that an audiobook vocalist doesn't force his or her vo

So I'm not in any way trying to demonize audiobooks by saying that I don't use them. I definitely do. I just think it's important to point out that I really don't enjoy listening to them much because it isn't the same as reading a real book.

Reading a real book really helps me to get invested in the story and characters. And I always find that I 'm more easily able to form a real, deep connection to the characters of what I'm reading if I can see them and visually connect to their words. Usually when I read, my mind is actively visualizing the book's imagery, which I find is something that can't quite be replicated when listening to someone else read it to me. 

I've had some friends tell me that they really enjoy audiobooks in part because they can make up their own interpretation of the story when they aren't seeing it played out the way the author intended on the page. I can understand this viewpoint, but I don't find much value in it. After all, couldn't I just retort that people don't really know it could have been intended any other way? And who's to say that an audiobook vocalist doesn't force his or her own views of

Is Listening to a Book Just as Good as Reading It?

Do you listen to audiobooks? What are the benefits, in your opinion, of listening instead of reading? Are there advantages to reading that cannot be gained by listening? Which method do you prefer? Why?

In my opinion, audiobooks are not a sufficient replacement for real books. I don't listen to audiobooks because I consider myself to be a visual learner, and while I suppose that good audiobook narrators aim to cater to me, it's just not the same for me. I really have to be seeing it in my mind's eye if I'm to get the full effect of a story. If I'm just listening to someone read it, I don't feel one bit of emotion or connection with the characters. And moreover, it's just that much easier for me to "switch off" when listening to someone else read - particularly if what I'm listening to isn't capturing my attention. Oftentimes, when I'm listening to an audiobook, I'll find myself daydreaming about times I'd rather forget, or something bad that happened today, or my looming deadlines... I just can't concentrate fully on what I'm listening to if my mind is wandering.

This isn't to say that audiobooks can't be tremendously useful, and I do use them occasionally. I mean, if I'm driving, I can't even pretend that it isn't ten times safer for me to be listening to someone else read instead of trying to read myself. I've had some friends tell me that they really enjoy audiobooks in part because they can make up their own interpretation of the story when they aren't seeing it played out the way the author intended on the page. I can understand this viewpoint, but I don't find much value in it. After all, couldn't I just retort that people don't really know it could have been intended any other way? And who's to say that an audiobook vocalist doesn't force his or her own views of a book or plot

Is Listening to a Book Just as Good as Reading It?

Do you listen to audiobooks? What are the benefits, in your opinion, of listening instead of reading? Are there advantages to reading that cannot be gained by listening? Which method do you prefer? Why?

---

In my opinion, audiobooks are not a sufficient replacement for real books. I don't listen to audiobooks because I consider myself to be a visual learner, and while I suppose that good audiobook narrators aim to cater to me, it's just not the same for me. I really have to be seeing it in my mind's eye if I'm to get the full effect of a story. If I'm just listening to someone read it, I don't feel one bit of emotion or connection with the characters. And moreover, it's just that much easier for me to "switch off" when listening to someone else read - particularly if what I'm listening to isn't capturing my attention. Oftentimes, when I'm listening to an audiobook, I'll find myself daydreaming about times I'd rather forget, or something bad that happened today, or my looming deadlines... I just can't concentrate fully on what I'm listening to if my mind is wandering.

This isn't to say that audiobooks can't be tremendously useful, and I do use them occasionally. I mean, if I'm driving, I can't even pretend that it isn't ten times safer for me to be listening to someone else read instead of trying to read myself. On my commute to and from school, I often find that listening to John Scalzi narrate his own audiobooks is enjoyable - even though I don't think I get as much out of the audiobooks as I do from reading them my own. Sometimes, listening to the audiobook version of my science textbook is sufficient to recall the information I need for an exam - although I will caveat that it is not sufficient to really understand it. So I'm not in any way trying to demonize audiobooks by saying that I don't use them. I definitely do. I just think it's important to point out that I really don't enjoy listening to them much because it isn't the same as reading a real book.

Reading a real book really helps me to get invested in the story and characters. And I always find that I 'm more easily able to form a real, deep connection to the characters of what I'm reading if I can see them and visually connect to their words. Usually when I read, my mind is actively visualizing the book's imagery, which I find is something that can't quite be replicated when listening to someone else read it to me. 

I've had some friends tell me that they really enjoy audiobooks in part because they can make up their own interpretation of the story when they aren't seeing it played out the way the author intended on the page. I can understand this viewpoint, but I don't find much value in it. After all, couldn't I just retort that people don't really know it could have been intended any other way? Do you listen to audiobooks? What are the benefits, in your opinion, of listening instead of reading? Are there advantages to reading that cannot be gained by listening? Which method do you prefer? Why?

---

In my opinion, audiobooks are not a sufficient replacement for real books. I don't listen to audiobooks because I consider myself to be a visual learner, and while I suppose that good audiobook narrators aim to cater to me, it's just not the same for me. I really have to be seeing it in my mind's eye if I'm to get the full effect of a story. If I'm just listening to someone read it, I don't feel one bit of emotion or connection with the characters. And moreover, it's just that much easier for me to "switch off" when listening to someone else read - particularly if what I'm listening to isn't capturing my attention. Oftentimes, when I'm listening to an audiobook, I'll find myself daydreaming about times I'd rather forget, or something bad that happened today, or my looming deadlines... I just can't concentrate fully on what I'm listening to if my mind is wandering.

This isn't to say that audiobooks can't be tremendously useful, and I do use them occasionally. I mean, if I'm driving, I can't even pretend that it isn't ten times safer for me to be listening to someone else read instead of trying to read myself. On my commute to and from school, I often find that listening to John Scalzi narrate his own audiobooks is enjoyable - even though I don't think I get as much out of the audiobooks as I do from reading them my own. Sometimes, listening to the audiobook version of my science textbook is sufficient to recall the information I need for an exam - although I will caveat that it is not sufficient to really understand it. So I'm not in any way trying to demonize audiobooks by saying that I don't use them. I definitely do. I just think it's important to point out that I really don't enjoy listening to them much because it isn't the same as reading a real book.

Reading a real book really helps me to get invested in the story and characters. And I always find that I 'm more easily able to form a real, deep connection to the characters of what I'm reading if I can see them and visually connect to their words. Usually when I read, my mind is actively visualizing the book's imagery, which I find is something that can't quite be replicated when listening to someone else read it to me. 

I've had some friends tell me that they really enjoy audiobooks in part because they can make up their own interpretation of the story when they aren't seeing it played out the way the author intended on the page. I can understand this viewpoint, but I don't find much value in it. After all, couldn't I just retort that people don't really know it could have been intended any other way? And who's to say that an audiobook vocalist doesn't force his or her own views of a book or plotline on their rea

And moreover, it's just that much easier for me to "switch off" when listening to someone else read - particularly if what I'm listening to isn't capturing my attention. Oftentimes, when I'm listening to an audiobook, I'll find myself daydreaming about times I'd rather forget, or something bad that happened today, or my looming deadlines... I just can't concentrate fully on what I'm listening to if my mind is wandering.

This isn't to say that audiobooks can't be tremendously useful, and I do use them occasionally. I mean, if I'm driving, I can't even pretend that it isn't ten times safer for me to be listening to someone else read instead of trying to read myself. On my commute to and from school, I often find that listening to John Scalzi narrate his own audiobooks is enjoyable - even though I don't think I get as much out of the audiobooks as I do from reading them my own. Sometimes, listening to the audiobook version of my science textbook is sufficient to recall the information I need for an exam - although I will caveat that it is not sufficient to really understand it. So I'm not in any way trying to demonize audiobooks by saying that I don't use them. I definitely do. I just think it's important to point out that I really don't enjoy listening to them much because it isn't the same as reading a real book.

Reading a real book really helps me to get invested in the story and characters. And I always find that I 'm more easily able to form a real, deep connection to the characters of what I'm reading if I can see them and visually connect to their words. Usually when I read, my mind is actively visualizing the book's imagery, which I find is something that can't quite be replicated when listening to someone else read it to me. 

I've had some friends tell me that they really enjoy audiobooks in part because they can make up their own interpretation of the story when they aren't seeing it played out the way the author intended on the page. I can understand this viewpoint, but I don't find much value in it. After all, couldn't I just retort that people don't really know it could have been intended any other way? And who's to say that an audiobook vocalist doesn't force his or her own views of a book or plotline on their listeners

I just can't concentrate fully on what I'm listening to if my mind is wandering.

This isn't to say that audiobooks can't be tremendously useful, and I do use them occasionally. I mean, if I'm driving, I can't even pretend that it isn't ten times safer for me to be listening to someone else read instead of trying to read myself. On my commute to and from school, I often find that listening to John Scalzi narrate his own audiobooks is enjoyable - even though I don't think I get as much out of the audiobooks as I do from reading them my own. Sometimes, listening to the audiobook version of my science textbook is sufficient to recall the information I need for an exam - although I will caveat that it is not sufficient to really understand it. So I'm not in any way trying to demonize audiobooks by saying that I don't use them. I definitely do. I just think it's important to point out that I really don't enjoy listening to them much because it isn't the same as reading a real book.

Reading a real book really helps me to get invested in the story and characters. And I always find that I 'm more easily able to form a real, deep connection to the characters of what I'm reading if I can see them and visually connect to their words. Usually when I read, my mind is actively visualizing the book's imagery, which I find is something that can't quite be replicated when listening to someone else read it to me. 

I've had some friends tell me that they really enjoy audiobooks in part because they can make up their own interpretation of the story when they aren't seeing it played out the way the author intended on the page. I can understand this viewpoint, but I don't find much value in it. After all, couldn't I just retort that people don't really know it could have been intended any other way? And who's to say that an audiobook vocalist doesn't force his or her own views of a book or plotline on their listeners? 

In co

I mean, if I'm driving, I can't even pretend that it isn't ten times safer for me to be listening to someone else read instead of trying to read myself. On my commute to and from school, I often find that listening to John Scalzi narrate his own audiobooks is enjoyable - even though I don't think I get as much out of the audiobooks as I do from reading them my own. Sometimes, listening to the audiobook version of my science textbook is sufficient to recall the information I need for an exam - although I will caveat that it is not sufficient to really understand it. So I'm not in any way trying to demonize audiobooks by saying that I don't use them. I definitely do. I just think it's important to point out that I really don't enjoy listening to them much because it isn't the same as reading a real book.

Reading a real book really helps me to get invested in the story and characters. And I always find that I 'm more easily able to form a real, deep connection to the characters of what I'm reading if I can see them and visually connect to their words. Usually when I read, my mind is actively visualizing the book's imagery, which I find is something that can't quite be replicated when listening to someone else read it to me. 

I've had some friends tell me that they really enjoy audiobooks in part because they can make up their own interpretation of the story when they aren't seeing it played out the way the author intended on the page. I can understand this viewpoint, but I don't find much value in it. After all, couldn't I just retort that people don't really know it could have been intended any other way? And who's to say that an audiobook vocalist doesn't force his or her own views of a book or plotline on their listeners? 

In conclusion, I a

Is Listening to a Book Just as Good as Reading It?

Do you listen to audiobooks? What are the benefits, in your opinion, of listening instead of reading? Are there advantages to reading that cannot be gained by listening? Which method do you prefer? Why?

In my opinion, audiobooks are not a sufficient replacement for real books. I don't listen to audiobooks because I consider myself to be a visual learner, and while I suppose that good audiobook narrators aim to cater to me, it's just not the same for me. I really have to be seeing it in my mind's eye if I'm to get the full effect of a story. If I'm just listening to someone read it, I don't feel one bit of emotion or connection with the characters. And moreover, it's just that much easier for me to "switch off" when listening to someone else read - particularly if what I'm listening to isn't capturing my attention. Oftentimes, when I'm listening to an audiobook, I'll find myself daydreaming about times I'd rather forget, or something bad that happened today, or my looming deadlines... I just can't concentrate fully on what I'm listening to if my mind is wandering.

This isn't to say that audiobooks can't be tremendously useful, and I do use them occasionally. Reading a real book really helps me to get invested in the story and characters. Usually when I read, my mind is actively visualizing the book's imagery, which I find is something that can't quite be replicated when listening to someone else read it to me. 

I've had some friends tell me that they really enjoy audiobooks in part because they can make up their own interpretation of the story when they aren't seeing it played out the way the author intended on the page. I can understand this viewpoint, but I don't find much value in it. After all, couldn't I just retort that people don't really know it could have been intended any other way? On my commute to and from school, I often find that listening to John Scalzi narrate his own audiobooks is enjoyable - even though I don't think I get as much out of the audiobooks as I do from reading them my own. Sometimes, listening to the audiobook version of my science textbook is sufficient to recall the information I need for an exam - although I will caveat that it is not sufficient to really understand it. So I'm not in any way trying to demonize audiobooks by saying that I don't use them. I definitely do. I just think it's important to point out that I really don't enjoy listening to them much because it isn't the same as reading a real book.

Reading a real book really helps me to get invested in the story and characters. And I always find that I 'm more easily able to form a real, deep connection to the characters of what I'm reading if I can see them and visually connect to their words. Usually when I read, my mind is actively visualizing the book's imagery, which I find is something that can't quite be replicated when listening to someone else read it to me. 

I've had some friends tell me that they really enjoy audiobooks in part because they can make up their own interpretation of the story when they aren't seeing it played out the way the author intended on the page. I can understand this viewpoint, but I don't find much value in it. After all, couldn't I just retort that people don't really know it could have been intended any other way? And who's to say that an audiobook vocalist doesn't force his or her own views of a book or plotline on their listeners? 

In conclusion, I am happy to sti

I don't listen to audiobooks because I consider myself to be a visual learner, and while I suppose that good audiobook narrators aim to cater to me, it's just not the same for me. I really have to be seeing it in my mind's eye if I'm to get the full effect of a story. If I'm just listening to someone read it, I don't feel one bit of emotion or connection with the characters. And moreover, it's just that much easier for me to "switch off" when listening to someone else read - particularly if what I'm listening to isn't capturing my attention. Oftentimes, when I'm listening to an audiobook, I'll find myself daydreaming about times I'd rather forget, or something bad that happened today, or my looming deadlines... On my commute to and from school, I often find that listening to John Scalzi narrate his own audiobooks is enjoyable - even though I don't think I get as much out of the audiobooks as I do from reading them my own. Sometimes, listening to the audiobook version of my science textbook is sufficient to recall the information I need for an exam - although I will caveat that it is not sufficient to really understand it. So I'm not in any way trying to demonize audiobooks by saying that I don't use them. I definitely do. I just think it's important to point out that I really don't enjoy listening to them much because it isn't the same as reading a real book.

Reading a real book really helps me to get invested in the story and characters. And I always find that I 'm more easily able to form a real, deep connection to the characters of what I'm reading if I can see them and visually connect to their words. Usually when I read, my mind is actively visualizing the book's imagery, which I find is something that can't quite be replicated when listening to someone else read it to me. 

I've had some friends tell me that they really enjoy audiobooks in part because they can make up their own interpretation of the story when they aren't seeing it played out the way the author intended on the page. I can understand this viewpoint, but I don't find much value in it. After all, couldn't I just retort that people don't really know it could have been intended any other way? And who's to say that an audiobook vocalist doesn't force his or her own views of a book or plotline on their listeners? 

In conclusion, I am happy to stick to reading

Do you listen to audiobooks? What are the benefits, in your opinion, of listening instead of reading? Are there advantages to reading that cannot be gained by listening? Which method do you prefer? Why?

I don't listen to audiobooks because I consider myself to be a visual learner, and while I suppose that good audiobook narrators aim to cater to me, it's just not the same for me. I really have to be seeing it in my mind's eye if I'm to get the full effect of a story. If I'm just listening to someone read it, I don't feel one bit of emotion or connection with the characters. On my commute to and from school, I often find that listening to John Scalzi narrate his own audiobooks is enjoyable - even though I don't think I get as much out of the audiobooks as I do from reading them my own. Sometimes, listening to the audiobook version of my science textbook is sufficient to recall the information I need for an exam - although I will caveat that it is not sufficient to really understand it. So I'm not in any way trying to demonize audiobooks by saying that I don't use them. I definitely do. I just think it's important to point out that I really don't enjoy listening to them much because it isn't the same as reading a real book.

Reading a real book really helps me to get invested in the story and characters. And I always find that I 'm more easily able to form a real, deep connection to the characters of what I'm reading if I can see them and visually connect to their words. Usually when I read, my mind is actively visualizing the book's imagery, which I find is something that can't quite be replicated when listening to someone else read it to me. 

I've had some friends tell me that they really enjoy audiobooks in part because they can make up their own interpretation of the story when they aren't seeing it played out the way the author intended on the page. I can understand this viewpoint, but I don't find much value in it. After all, couldn't I just retort that people don't really know it could have been intended any other way? And who's to say that an audiobook vocalist doesn't force his or her own views of a book or plotline on their listeners? 

In conclusion, I am happy to stick to reading real books. I

Is Listening to a Book Just as Good as Reading It?

Do you listen to audiobooks? What are the benefits, in your opinion, of listening instead of reading? Are there advantages to reading that cannot be gained by listening? Which method do you prefer? Why?

---

In my opinion, audiobooks are not a sufficient replacement for real books. I don't listen to audiobooks because I consider myself to be a visual learner, and while I suppose that good audiobook narrators aim to cater to me, it's just not the same for me. I really have to be seeing it in my mind's eye if I'm to get the full effect of a story. If I'm just listening to someone read it, I don't feel one bit of emotion or connection with the characters. And moreover, it's just that much easier for me to "switch off" when listening to someone else read - particularly if what I'm listening to isn't capturing my attention. Oftentimes, when I'm listening to an audiobook, I'll find myself daydreaming about times I'd rather forget, or something bad that happened today, or my looming deadlines... I just can't concentrate fully on what I'm listening to if my mind is wandering.

This isn't to say that audiobooks can't be tremendously useful, and I do use them occasionally. I mean, if I'm driving, I can't even pretend that it isn't ten times safer for me to be listening to someone else read instead of trying to read myself. On my commute to and from school, I often find that listening to John Scalzi narrate his own audiobooks is enjoyable - even though I don't think I get as much out of the audiobooks as I do from reading them my own. Sometimes, listening to the audiobook version of my science textbook is sufficient to recall the information I need for an exam - although I will caveat that it is not sufficient to really understand it. So I'm not in any way trying to demonize audiobooks by saying that I don't use them. I definitely do. I just think it's important to point out that I really don't enjoy listening to them much because it isn't the same as reading a real book.

Reading a real book really helps me to get invested in the story and characters. And I always find that I 'm more easily able to form a real, deep connection to the characters of what I'm reading if I can see them and visually connect to their words. Usually when I read, my mind is actively visualizing the book's imagery, which I find is something that can't quite be replicated when listening to someone else read it to me. 

I've had some friends tell me that they really enjoy audiobooks in part because they can make up their own interpretation of the story when they aren't seeing it played out the way the author intended on the page. I can understand this viewpoint, but I don't find much value in it. After all, couldn't I just retort that people don't really know it could have been intended any other way? And who's to say that an audiobook vocalist doesn't force his or her own views of a book or plotline on their listeners? 

In conclusion, I am happy to stick to reading real books. I think that

Is Listening to a Book Just as Good as Reading It?

Do you listen to audiobooks? What are the benefits, in your opinion, of listening instead of reading? Are there advantages to reading that cannot be gained by listening? Which method do you prefer? Why?

---

In my opinion, audiobooks are not a sufficient replacement for real books. I don't listen to audiobooks because I consider myself to be a visual learner, and while I suppose that good audiobook narrators aim to cater to me, it's just not the same for me. I really have to be seeing it in my mind's eye if I'm to get the full effect of a story. If I'm just listening to someone read it, I don't feel one bit of emotion or connection with the characters. And moreover, it's just that much easier for me to "switch off" when listening to someone else read - particularly if what I'm listening to isn't capturing my attention. Oftentimes, when I'm listening to an audiobook, I'll find myself daydreaming about times I'd rather forget, or something bad that happened today, or my looming deadlines... I just can't concentrate fully on what I'm listening to if my mind is wandering.

This isn't to say that audiobooks can't be tremendously useful, and I do use them occasionally. I mean, if I'm driving, I can't even pretend that it isn't ten times safer for me to be listening to someone else read instead of trying to read myself. Sometimes, listening to the audiobook version of my science textbook is sufficient to recall the information I need for an exam - although I will caveat that it is not sufficient to really understand it. So I'm not in any way trying to demonize audiobooks by saying that I don't use them. I definitely do. I just think it's important to point out that I really don't enjoy listening to them much because it isn't the same as reading a real book.

Reading a real book really helps me to get invested in the story and characters. And I always find that I 'm more easily able to form a real, deep connection to the characters of what I'm reading if I can see them and visually connect to their words. Usually when I read, my mind is actively visualizing the book's imagery, which I find is something that can't quite be replicated when listening to someone else read it to me. 

I've had some friends tell me that they really enjoy audiobooks in part because they can make up their own interpretation of the story when they aren't seeing it played out the way the author intended on the page. I can understand this viewpoint, but I don't find much value in it. After all, couldn't I just retort that people don't really know it could have been intended any other way? And who's to say that an audiobook vocalist doesn't force his or her own views of a book or plotline on their listeners? 

In conclusion, I am happy to stick to reading real books. I think that there's a lot to be said for the real, tangible relationship between a reader and their pages.

Do you listen to audiobooks? What are the benefits, in your opinion, of listening instead of reading? Are there advantages to reading that cannot be gained by listening? Which method do you prefer? Why?

---

In my opinion, audiobooks are not a sufficient replacement for real books. I don't listen to audiobooks because I consider myself to be a visual learner, and while I suppose that good audiobook narrators aim to cater to me, it's just not the same for me. I really have to be seeing it in my mind's eye if I'm to get the full effect of a story. If I'm just listening to someone read it, I don't feel one bit of emotion or connection with the characters. And moreover, it's just that much easier for me to "switch off" when listening to someone else read - particularly if what I'm listening to isn't capturing my attention. Oftentimes, when I'm listening to an audiobook, I'll find myself daydreaming about times I'd rather forget, or something bad that happened today, or my looming deadlines... I just can't concentrate fully on what I'm listening to if my mind is wandering.

This isn't to say that audiobooks can't be tremendously useful, and I do use them occasionally. I mean, if I'm driving, I can't even pretend that it isn't ten times safer for me to be listening to someone else read instead of trying to read myself. On my commute to and from school, I often find that listening to John Scalzi narrate his own audiobooks is enjoyable - even though I don't think I get as much out of the audiobooks as I do from reading them my own. Sometimes, listening to the audiobook version of my science textbook is sufficient to recall the information I need for an exam - although I will caveat that it is not sufficient to really understand it. So I'm not in any way trying to demonize audiobooks by saying that I don't use them. I definitely do. I just think it's important to point out that I really don't enjoy listening to them much because it isn't the same as reading a real book.

Reading a real book really helps me to get invested in the story and characters. And I always find that I 'm more easily able to form a real, deep connection to the characters of what I'm reading if I can see them and visually connect to their words. Usually when I read, my mind is actively visualizing the book's imagery, which I find is something that can't quite be replicated when listening to someone else read it to me. 

I've had some friends tell me that they really enjoy audiobooks in part because they can make up their own interpretation of the story when they aren't seeing it played out the way the author intended on the page. I can understand this viewpoint, but I don't find much value in it. After all, couldn't I just retort that people don't really know it could have been intended any other way? And who's to say that an audiobook vocalist doesn't force his or her own views of a book or plotline on their listeners? 

In conclusion, I am happy to stick to reading real books. I think that there's a lot to be said for the real, tangible relationship between a reader and their pages. Plus, the

I just think it's important to point out that I really don't enjoy listening to them much because it isn't the same as reading a real book.

Reading a real book really helps me to get invested in the story and characters. And I always find that I 'm more easily able to form a real, deep connection to the characters of what I'm reading if I can see them and visually connect to their words. Usually when I read, my mind is actively visualizing the book's imagery, which I find is something that can't quite be replicated when listening to someone else read it to me. 

I've had some friends tell me that they really enjoy audiobooks in part because they can make up their own interpretation of the story when they aren't seeing it played out the way the author intended on the page. I can understand this viewpoint, but I don't find much value in it. After all, couldn't I just retort that people don't really know it could have been intended any other way? And who's to say that an audiobook vocalist doesn't force his or her own views of a book or plotline on their listeners? 

In conclusion, I am happy to stick to reading real books. I think that there's a lot to be said for the real, tangible relationship between a reader and their pages. Plus, there's defini

Is Listening to a Book Just as Good as Reading It?

Do you listen to audiobooks? What are the benefits, in your opinion, of listening instead of reading? Are there advantages to reading that cannot be gained by listening? Which method do you prefer? Why?

---

In my opinion, audiobooks are not a sufficient replacement for real books. I don't listen to audiobooks because I consider myself to be a visual learner, and while I suppose that good audiobook narrators aim to cater to me, it's just not the same for me. I really have to be seeing it in my mind's eye if I'm to get the full effect of a story. If I'm just listening to someone read it, I don't feel one bit of emotion or connection with the characters. And moreover, it's just that much easier for me to "switch off" when listening to someone else read - particularly if what I'm listening to isn't capturing my attention. Oftentimes, when I'm listening to an audiobook, I'll find myself daydreaming about times I'd rather forget, or something bad that happened today, or my looming deadlines... I just can't concentrate fully on what I'm listening to if my mind is wandering.

This isn't to say that audiobooks can't be tremendously useful, and I do use them occasionally. I mean, if I'm driving, I can't even pretend that it isn't ten times safer for me to be listening to someone else read instead of trying to read myself. On my commute to and from school, I often find that listening to John Scalzi narrate his own audiobooks is enjoyable - even though I don't think I get as much out of the audiobooks as I do from reading them my own. Sometimes, listening to the audiobook version of my science textbook is sufficient to recall the information I need for an exam - although I will caveat that it is not sufficient to really understand it. So I'm not in any way trying to demonize audiobooks by saying that I don't use them. I definitely do. I just think it's important to point out that I really don't enjoy listening to them much because it isn't the same as reading a real book.

Reading a real book really helps me to get invested in the story and characters. I've had some friends tell me that they really enjoy audiobooks in part because they can make up their own interpretation of the story when they aren't seeing it played out the way the author intended on the page. And who's to say that an audiobook vocalist doesn't force his or her own views of a book or plotline on their listeners? 

In conclusion, I am happy to stick to reading real books. I think that there's a lot to be said for the real, tangible relationship between a reader and their pages. Plus, there's definit

I don't listen to audiobooks because I consider myself to be a visual learner, and while I suppose that good audiobook narrators aim to cater to me, it's just not the same for me. I really have to be seeing it in my mind's eye if I'm to get the full effect of a story. If I'm just listening to someone read it, I don't feel one bit of emotion or connection with the characters. And moreover, it's just that much easier for me to "switch off" when listening to someone else read - particularly if what I'm listening to isn't capturing my attention. Oftentimes, when I'm listening to an audiobook, I'll find myself daydreaming about times I'd rather forget, or something bad that happened today, or my looming deadlines... I just can't concentrate fully on what I'm listening to if my mind is wandering.

This isn't to say that audiobooks can't be tremendously useful, and I do use them occasionally. I mean, if I'm driving, I can't even pretend that it isn't ten times safer for me to be listening to someone else read instead of trying to read myself. On my commute to and from school, I often find that listening to John Scalzi narrate his own audiobooks is enjoyable - even though I don't think I get as much out of the audiobooks as I do from reading them my own. Sometimes, listening to the audiobook version of my science textbook is sufficient to recall the information I need for an exam - although I will caveat that it is not sufficient to really understand it. So I'm not in any way trying to demonize audiobooks by saying that I don't use them. I definitely do. I just think it's important to point out that I really don't enjoy listening to them much because it isn't the same as reading a real book.

Reading a real book really helps me to get invested in the story and characters. And I always find that I 'm more easily able to form a real, deep connection to the characters of what I'm reading if I can see them and visually connect to their words. Usually when I read, my mind is actively visualizing the book's imagery, which I find is something that can't quite be replicated when listening to someone else read it to me. 

I've had some friends tell me that they really enjoy audiobooks in part because they can make up their own interpretation of the story when they aren't seeing it played out the way the author intended on the page. I can understand this viewpoint, but I don't find much value in it. After all, couldn't I just retort that people don't really know it could have been intended any other way? And who's to say that an audiobook vocalist doesn't force his or her own views of a book or plotline on their listeners? 

In conclusion, I am happy to stick to reading real books. I think that there's a lot to be said for the real, tangible relationship between a reader and their pages. Plus, there's definitely a lot to b

Reading a real book really helps me to get invested in the story and characters. And I always find that I 'm more easily able to form a real, deep connection to the characters of what I'm reading if I can see them and visually connect to their words. Usually when I read, my mind is actively visualizing the book's imagery, which I find is something that can't quite be replicated when listening to someone else read it to me. 

I've had some friends tell me that they really enjoy audiobooks in part because they can make up their own interpretation of the story when they aren't seeing it played out the way the author intended on the page. I can understand this viewpoint, but I don't find much value in it. After all, couldn't I just retort that people don't really know it could have been intended any other way? And who's to say that an audiobook vocalist doesn't force his or her own views of a book or plotline on their listeners? 

In conclusion, I am happy to stick to reading real books. I think that there's a lot to be said for the real, tangible relationship between a reader and their pages. Plus, there's definitely a lot to be said for the tactile experience that a real book allows - that's a whole other argument for another day.

Is Listening to a Book Just as Good as Reading It?

Do you listen to audiobooks? What are the benefits, in your opinion, of listening instead of reading? Are there advantages to reading that cannot be gained by listening? Which method do you prefer? Why?

---

In my opinion, audiobooks are not a sufficient replacement for real books. I don't listen to audiobooks because I consider myself to be a visual learner, and while I suppose that good audiobook narrators aim to cater to me, it's just not the same for me. I really have to be seeing it in my mind's eye if I'm to get the full effect of a story. If I'm just listening to someone read it, I don't feel one bit of emotion or connection with the characters. And moreover, it's just that much easier for me to "switch off" when listening to someone else read - particularly if what I'm listening to isn't capturing my attention. Oftentimes, when I'm listening to an audiobook, I'll find myself daydreaming about times I'd rather forget, or something bad that happened today, or my looming deadlines... I just can't concentrate fully on what I'm listening to if my mind is wandering.

This isn't to say that audiobooks can't be tremendously useful, and I do use them occasionally. I mean, if I'm driving, I can't even pretend that it isn't ten times safer for me to be listening to someone else read instead of trying to read myself. On my commute to and from school, I often find that listening to John Scalzi narrate his own audiobooks is enjoyable - even though I don't think I get as much out of the audiobooks as I do from reading them my own. Sometimes, listening to the audiobook version of my science textbook is sufficient to recall the information I need for an exam - although I will caveat that it is not sufficient to really understand it. So I'm not in any way trying to demonize audiobooks by saying that I don't use them. I definitely do. I just think it's important to point out that I really don't enjoy listening to them much because it isn't the same as reading a real book.

And I always find that I 'm more easily able to form a real, deep connection to the characters of what I'm reading if I can see them and visually connect to their words. And who's to say that an audiobook vocalist doesn't force his or her own views of a book or plotline on their listeners? U

Plus, there's definitely a lot to be said for the tactile experience that a real book allows - that's a whole other argument for another day.

I can understand this viewpoint, but I don't find much value in it. After all, couldn't I just retort that people don't really know it could have been intended any other way? And who's to say that an audiobook vocalist doesn't force his or her own views of a book or plotline on their listeners? I have 

In conclusion, I am happy to stick to reading real books. I think that there's a lot to be said for the real, tangible relationship between a reader and their pages. Plus, there's definitely a lot to be said for the tactile experience that a real book allows - that's a whole other argument for another day.

Is Listening to a Book Just as Good as Reading It?

Do you listen to audiobooks? What are the benefits, in your opinion, of listening instead of reading? Are there advantages to reading that cannot be gained by listening? Which method do you prefer? Why?

---

In my opinion, audiobooks are not a sufficient replacement for real books. I don't listen to audiobooks because I consider myself to be a visual learner, and while I suppose that good audiobook narrators aim to cater to me, it's just not the same for me. I really have to be seeing it in my mind's eye if I'm to get the full effect of a story. If I'm just listening to someone read it, I don't feel one bit of emotion or connection with the characters. And moreover, it's just that much easier for me to "switch off" when listening to someone else read - particularly if what I'm listening to isn't capturing my attention. Oftentimes, when I'm listening to an audiobook, I'll find myself daydreaming about times I'd rather forget, or something bad that happened today, or my looming deadlines... I just can't concentrate fully on what I'm listening to if my mind is wandering.

This isn't to say that audiobooks can't be tremendously useful, and I do use them occasionally. I mean, if I'm driving, I can't even pretend that it isn't ten times safer for me to be listening to someone else read instead of trying to read myself. On my commute to and from school, I often find that listening to John Scalzi narrate his own audiobooks is enjoyable - even though I don't think I get as much out of the audiobooks as I do from reading them my own. Sometimes, listening to the audiobook version of my science textbook is sufficient to recall the information I need for an exam - although I will caveat that it is not sufficient to really understand it. So I'm not in any way trying to demonize audiobooks by saying that I don't use them. I definitely do. I just think it's important to point out that I really don't enjoy listening to them much because it isn't the same as reading a real book.

Reading a real book really helps me to get invested in the story and characters. And I always find that I 'm more easily able to form a real, deep connection to the characters of what I'm reading if I can see them and visually connect to their words. Usually when I read, my mind is actively visualizing the book's imagery, which I find is something that can't quite be replicated when listening to someone else read it to me. 

I've had some friends tell me that they really enjoy audiobooks in part because they can make up their own interpretation of the story when they aren't seeing it played out the way the author intended on the page. I can understand this viewpoint, but I don't find much value in it. After all, couldn't I just retort that people don't really know it could have been intended any other way? And who's to say that an audiobook vocalist doesn't force his or her own views of a book or plotline on their listeners? I have n

In conclusion, I am happy to stick to reading real books. I think that there's a lot to be said for the real, tangible relationship between a reader and their pages. Plus, there's definitely a lot to be said for the tactile experience that a real book allows - that's a whole other argument for another day.

In conclusion, I am happy to stick to reading real books. I think that there's a lot to be said for the real, tangible relationship between a reader and their pages. Plus, there's definitely a lot to be said for the tactile experience that a real book allows - that's a whole other argument for another day.

Is Listening to a Book Just as Good as Reading It?

Do you listen to audiobooks? What are the benefits, in your opinion, of listening instead of reading? Are there advantages to reading that cannot be gained by listening? Which method do you prefer? Why?

---

In my opinion, audiobooks are not a sufficient replacement for real books. I don't listen to audiobooks because I consider myself to be a visual learner, and while I suppose that good audiobook narrators aim to cater to me, it's just not the same for me. I really have to be seeing it in my mind's eye if I'm to get the full effect of a story. If I'm just listening to someone read it, I don't feel one bit of emotion or connection with the characters. And moreover, it's just that much easier for me to "switch off" when listening to someone else read - particularly if what I'm listening to isn't capturing my attention. Oftentimes, when I'm listening to an audiobook, I'll find myself daydreaming about times I'd rather forget, or something bad that happened today, or my looming deadlines... I just can't concentrate fully on what I'm listening to if my mind is wandering.

This isn't to say that audiobooks can't be tremendously useful, and I do use them occasionally. I mean, if I'm driving, I can't even pretend that it isn't ten times safer for me to be listening to someone else read instead of trying to read myself. On my commute to and from school, I often find that listening to John Scalzi narrate his own audiobooks is enjoyable - even though I don't think I get as much out of the audiobooks as I do from reading them my own. Sometimes, listening to the audiobook version of my science textbook is sufficient to recall the information I need for an exam - although I will caveat that it is not sufficient to really understand it. So I'm not in any way trying to demonize audiobooks by saying that I don't use them. I definitely do. I just think it's important to point out that I really don't enjoy listening to them much because it isn't the same as reading a real book.

Reading a real book really helps me to get invested in the story and characters. And I always find that I 'm more easily able to form a real, deep connection to the characters of what I'm reading if I can see them and visually connect to their words. Usually when I read, my mind is actively visualizing the book's imagery, which I find is something that can't quite be replicated when listening to someone else read it to me. 

I've had some friends tell me that they really enjoy audiobooks in part because they can make up their own interpretation of the story when they aren't seeing it played out the way the author intended on the page. I can understand this viewpoint, but I don't find much value in it. After all, couldn't I just retort that people don't really know it could have been intended any other way? And who's to say that an audiobook vocalist doesn't force his or her own views of a book or plotline on their listeners? I have never felt 

In conclusion, I am happy to stick to reading real books. I think that there's a lot to be said for the real, tangible relationship between a reader and their pages. Plus, there's definitely a lot to be said for the tactile experience that a real book allows - that's a whole other argument for another day.

Do you listen to audiobooks? What are the benefits, in your opinion, of listening instead of reading? Are there advantages to reading that cannot be gained by listening? Which method do you prefer? Why?

---

In my opinion, audiobooks are not a sufficient replacement for real books. I don't listen to audiobooks because I consider myself to be a visual learner, and while I suppose that good audiobook narrators aim to cater to me, it's just not the same for me. I really have to be seeing it in my mind's eye if I'm to get the full effect of a story. If I'm just listening to someone read it, I don't feel one bit of emotion or connection with the characters. And moreover, it's just that much easier for me to "switch off" when listening to someone else read - particularly if what I'm listening to isn't capturing my attention. Oftentimes, when I'm listening to an audiobook, I'll find myself daydreaming about times I'd rather forget, or something bad that happened today, or my looming deadlines... I just can't concentrate fully on what I'm listening to if my mind is wandering.

This isn't to say that audiobooks can't be tremendously useful, and I do use them occasionally. I mean, if I'm driving, I can't even pretend that it isn't ten times safer for me to be listening to someone else read instead of trying to read myself. On my commute to and from school, I often find that listening to John Scalzi narrate his own audiobooks is enjoyable - even though I don't think I get as much out of the audiobooks as I do from reading them my own. Sometimes, listening to the audiobook version of my science textbook is sufficient to recall the information I need for an exam - although I will caveat that it is not sufficient to really understand it. So I'm not in any way trying to demonize audiobooks by saying that I don't use them. I definitely do. I just think it's important to point out that I really don't enjoy listening to them much because it isn't the same as reading a real book.

Reading a real book really helps me to get invested in the story and characters. And I always find that I 'm more easily able to form a real, deep connection to the characters of what I'm reading if I can see them and visually connect to their words. Usually when I read, my mind is actively visualizing the book's imagery, which I find is something that can't quite be replicated when listening to someone else read it to me. 

I've had some friends tell me that they really enjoy audiobooks in part because they can make up their own interpretation of the story when they aren't seeing it played out the way the author intended on the page. I can understand this viewpoint, but I don't find much value in it. After all, couldn't I just retort that people don't really know it could have been intended any other way? And who's to say that an audiobook vocalist doesn't force his or her own views of a book or plotline on their listeners? I have never felt that I cou

In conclusion, I am happy to stick to reading real books. I think that there's a lot to be said for the real, tangible relationship between a reader and their pages. Plus, there's definitely a lot to be said for the tactile experience that a real book allows - that's a whole other argument for another day.

I don't listen to audiobooks because I consider myself to be a visual learner, and while I suppose that good audiobook narrators aim to cater to me, it's just not the same for me. I really have to be seeing it in my mind's eye if I'm to get the full effect of a story. If I'm just listening to someone read it, I don't feel one bit of emotion or connection with the characters. And moreover, it's just that much easier for me to "switch off" when listening to someone else read - particularly if what I'm listening to isn't capturing my attention. Oftentimes, when I'm listening to an audiobook, I'll find myself daydreaming about times I'd rather forget, or something bad that happened today, or my looming deadlines... I just can't concentrate fully on what I'm listening to if my mind is wandering.

This isn't to say that audiobooks can't be tremendously useful, and I do use them occasionally. I mean, if I'm driving, I can't even pretend that it isn't ten times safer for me to be listening to someone else read instead of trying to read myself. On my commute to and from school, I often find that listening to John Scalzi narrate his own audiobooks is enjoyable - even though I don't think I get as much out of the audiobooks as I do from reading them my own. Sometimes, listening to the audiobook version of my science textbook is sufficient to recall the information I need for an exam - although I will caveat that it is not sufficient to really understand it. So I'm not in any way trying to demonize audiobooks by saying that I don't use them. I definitely do. I just think it's important to point out that I really don't enjoy listening to them much because it isn't the same as reading a real book.

Reading a real book really helps me to get invested in the story and characters. And I always find that I 'm more easily able to form a real, deep connection to the characters of what I'm reading if I can see them and visually connect to their words. Usually when I read, my mind is actively visualizing the book's imagery, which I find is something that can't quite be replicated when listening to someone else read it to me. 

I've had some friends tell me that they really enjoy audiobooks in part because they can make up their own interpretation of the story when they aren't seeing it played out the way the author intended on the page. I can understand this viewpoint, but I don't find much value in it. After all, couldn't I just retort that people don't really know it could have been intended any other way? And who's to say that an audiobook vocalist doesn't force his or her own views of a book or plotline on their listeners? I have never felt that I couldn't make

In conclusion, I am happy to stick to reading real books. I think that there's a lot to be said for the real, tangible relationship between a reader and their pages. Plus, there's definitely a lot to be said for the tactile experience that a real book allows - that's a whole other argument for another day.

Is Listening to a Book Just as Good as Reading It?

Do you listen to audiobooks? What are the benefits, in your opinion, of listening instead of reading? Are there advantages to reading that cannot be gained by listening? Which method do you prefer? Why?

And moreover, it's just that much easier for me to "switch off" when listening to someone else read - particularly if what I'm listening to isn't capturing my attention. Oftentimes, when I'm listening to an audiobook, I'll find myself daydreaming about times I'd rather forget, or something bad that happened today, or my looming deadlines... I just can't concentrate fully on what I'm listening to if my mind is wandering.

This isn't to say that audiobooks can't be tremendously useful, and I do use them occasionally. I mean, if I'm driving, I can't even pretend that it isn't ten times safer for me to be listening to someone else read instead of trying to read myself. On my commute to and from school, I often find that listening to John Scalzi narrate his own audiobooks is enjoyable - even though I don't think I get as much out of the audiobooks as I do from reading them my own. Sometimes, listening to the audiobook version of my science textbook is sufficient to recall the information I need for an exam - although I will caveat that it is not sufficient to really understand it. So I'm not in any way trying to demonize audiobooks by saying that I don't use them. I definitely do. I just think it's important to point out that I really don't enjoy listening to them much because it isn't the same as reading a real book.

Reading a real book really helps me to get invested in the story and characters. And I always find that I 'm more easily able to form a real, deep connection to the characters of what I'm reading if I can see them and visually connect to their words. Usually when I read, my mind is actively visualizing the book's imagery, which I find is something that can't quite be replicated when listening to someone else read it to me. 

I've had some friends tell me that they really enjoy audiobooks in part because they can make up their own interpretation of the story when they aren't seeing it played out the way the author intended on the page. I can understand this viewpoint, but I don't find much value in it. After all, couldn't I just retort that people don't really know it could have been intended any other way? And who's to say that an audiobook vocalist doesn't force his or her own views of a book or plotline on their listeners? I have never felt that I couldn't make up my own

In conclusion, I am happy to stick to reading real books. I think that there's a lot to be said for the real, tangible relationship between a reader and their pages. Plus, there's definitely a lot to be said for the tactile experience that a real book allows - that's a whole other argument for another day.

And moreover, it's just that much easier for me to "switch off" when listening to someone else read - particularly if what I'm listening to isn't capturing my attention. Oftentimes, when I'm listening to an audiobook, I'll find myself daydreaming about times I'd rather forget, or something bad that happened today, or my looming deadlines... I just can't concentrate fully on what I'm listening to if my mind is wandering.

This isn't to say that audiobooks can't be tremendously useful, and I do use them occasionally. I mean, if I'm driving, I can't even pretend that it isn't ten times safer for me to be listening to someone else read instead of trying to read myself. On my commute to and from school, I often find that listening to John Scalzi narrate his own audiobooks is enjoyable - even though I don't think I get as much out of the audiobooks as I do from reading them my own. Sometimes, listening to the audiobook version of my science textbook is sufficient to recall the information I need for an exam - although I will caveat that it is not sufficient to really understand it. So I'm not in any way trying to demonize audiobooks by saying that I don't use them. I definitely do. I just think it's important to point out that I really don't enjoy listening to them much because it isn't the same as reading a real book.

Reading a real book really helps me to get invested in the story and characters. And I always find that I 'm more easily able to form a real, deep connection to the characters of what I'm reading if I can see them and visually connect to their words. Usually when I read, my mind is actively visualizing the book's imagery, which I find is something that can't quite be replicated when listening to someone else read it to me. 

I've had some friends tell me that they really enjoy audiobooks in part because they can make up their own interpretation of the story when they aren't seeing it played out the way the author intended on the page. I can understand this viewpoint, but I don't find much value in it. After all, couldn't I just retort that people don't really know it could have been intended any other way? And who's to say that an audiobook vocalist doesn't force his or her own views of a book or plotline on their listeners? I have never felt that I couldn't make up my own i

In conclusion, I am happy to stick to reading real books. I think that there's a lot to be said for the real, tangible relationship between a reader and their pages. Plus, there's definitely a lot to be said for the tactile experience that a real book allows - that's a whole other argument for another day.

I really have to be seeing it in my mind's eye if I'm to get the full effect of a story. If I'm just listening to someone read it, I don't feel one bit of emotion or connection with the characters. And moreover, it's just that much easier for me to "switch off" when listening to someone else read - particularly if what I'm listening to isn't capturing my attention. Oftentimes, when I'm listening to an audiobook, I'll find myself daydreaming about times I'd rather forget, or something bad that happened today, or my looming deadlines... I just can't concentrate fully on what I'm listening to if my mind is wandering.

This isn't to say that audiobooks can't be tremendously useful, and I do use them occasionally. I mean, if I'm driving, I can't even pretend that it isn't ten times safer for me to be listening to someone else read instead of trying to read myself. On my commute to and from school, I often find that listening to John Scalzi narrate his own audiobooks is enjoyable - even though I don't think I get as much out of the audiobooks as I do from reading them my own. Sometimes, listening to the audiobook version of my science textbook is sufficient to recall the information I need for an exam - although I will caveat that it is not sufficient to really understand it. So I'm not in any way trying to demonize audiobooks by saying that I don't use them. I definitely do. I just think it's important to point out that I really don't enjoy listening to them much because it isn't the same as reading a real book.

Reading a real book really helps me to get invested in the story and characters. And I always find that I 'm more easily able to form a real, deep connection to the characters of what I'm reading if I can see them and visually connect to their words. Usually when I read, my mind is actively visualizing the book's imagery, which I find is something that can't quite be replicated when listening to someone else read it to me. 

I've had some friends tell me that they really enjoy audiobooks in part because they can make up their own interpretation of the story when they aren't seeing it played out the way the author intended on the page. I can understand this viewpoint, but I don't find much value in it. After all, couldn't I just retort that people don't really know it could have been intended any other way? And who's to say that an audiobook vocalist doesn't force his or her own views of a book or plotline on their listeners? I have never felt that I couldn't make up my own interpretat

In conclusion, I am happy to stick to reading real books. I think that there's a lot to be said for the real, tangible relationship between a reader and their pages. Plus, there's definitely a lot to be said for the tactile experience that a real book allows - that's a whole other argument for another day.

I really have to be seeing it in my mind's eye if I'm to get the full effect of a story. If I'm just listening to someone read it, I don't feel one bit of emotion or connection with the characters. And moreover, it's just that much easier for me to "switch off" when listening to someone else read - particularly if what I'm listening to isn't capturing my attention. Oftentimes, when I'm listening to an audiobook, I'll find myself daydreaming about times I'd rather forget, or something bad that happened today, or my looming deadlines... I just can't concentrate fully on what I'm listening to if my mind is wandering.

This isn't to say that audiobooks can't be tremendously useful, and I do use them occasionally. I mean, if I'm driving, I can't even pretend that it isn't ten times safer for me to be listening to someone else read instead of trying to read myself. On my commute to and from school, I often find that listening to John Scalzi narrate his own audiobooks is enjoyable - even though I don't think I get as much out of the audiobooks as I do from reading them my own. Sometimes, listening to the audiobook version of my science textbook is sufficient to recall the information I need for an exam - although I will caveat that it is not sufficient to really understand it. So I'm not in any way trying to demonize audiobooks by saying that I don't use them. I definitely do. I just think it's important to point out that I really don't enjoy listening to them much because it isn't the same as reading a real book.

Reading a real book really helps me to get invested in the story and characters. And I always find that I 'm more easily able to form a real, deep connection to the characters of what I'm reading if I can see them and visually connect to their words. Usually when I read, my mind is actively visualizing the book's imagery, which I find is something that can't quite be replicated when listening to someone else read it to me. 

I've had some friends tell me that they really enjoy audiobooks in part because they can make up their own interpretation of the story when they aren't seeing it played out the way the author intended on the page. I can understand this viewpoint, but I don't find much value in it. After all, couldn't I just retort that people don't really know it could have been intended any other way? And who's to say that an audiobook vocalist doesn't force his or her own views of a book or plotline on their listeners? I have never felt that I couldn't make up my own interpretatio o

In conclusion, I am happy to stick to reading real books. I think that there's a lot to be said for the real, tangible relationship between a reader and their pages. Plus, there's definitely a lot to be said for the tactile experience that a real book allows - that's a whole other argument for another day.

I really have to be seeing it in my mind's eye if I'm to get the full effect of a story. If I'm just listening to someone read it, I don't feel one bit of emotion or connection with the characters. And moreover, it's just that much easier for me to "switch off" when listening to someone else read - particularly if what I'm listening to isn't capturing my attention. Oftentimes, when I'm listening to an audiobook, I'll find myself daydreaming about times I'd rather forget, or something bad that happened today, or my looming deadlines... I just can't concentrate fully on what I'm listening to if my mind is wandering.

This isn't to say that audiobooks can't be tremendously useful, and I do use them occasionally. I mean, if I'm driving, I can't even pretend that it isn't ten times safer for me to be listening to someone else read instead of trying to read myself. On my commute to and from school, I often find that listening to John Scalzi narrate his own audiobooks is enjoyable - even though I don't think I get as much out of the audiobooks as I do from reading them my own. Sometimes, listening to the audiobook version of my science textbook is sufficient to recall the information I need for an exam - although I will caveat that it is not sufficient to really understand it. So I'm not in any way trying to demonize audiobooks by saying that I don't use them. I definitely do. I just think it's important to point out that I really don't enjoy listening to them much because it isn't the same as reading a real book.

Reading a real book really helps me to get invested in the story and characters. And I always find that I 'm more easily able to form a real, deep connection to the characters of what I'm reading if I can see them and visually connect to their words. Usually when I read, my mind is actively visualizing the book's imagery, which I find is something that can't quite be replicated when listening to someone else read it to me. 

I've had some friends tell me that they really enjoy audiobooks in part because they can make up their own interpretation of the story when they aren't seeing it played out the way the author intended on the page. I can understand this viewpoint, but I don't find much value in it. After all, couldn't I just retort that people don't really know it could have been intended any other way? And who's to say that an audiobook vocalist doesn't force his or her own views of a book or plotline on their listeners? I have never felt that I couldn't make up my own interpretation of an 

In conclusion, I am happy to stick to reading real books. I think that there's a lot to be said for the real, tangible relationship between a reader and their pages. Plus, there's definitely a lot to be said for the tactile experience that a real book allows - that's a whole other argument for another day.
